articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Block Exits for Iraq Insurgents
articles.snippet: American forces have been confounded by insurgents who have slipped away only to fight another day.
articles.abstract: American forces have been confounded by insurgents who have slipped away only to fight another day.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 19 — In more than four years in Iraq, American forces have been confounded by insurgents who have often slipped away only to fight another day. The war in Iraq has been likened to the arcade game of whack-a-mole, where as soon as you knock down one mole another pops up.

articles.headline: Home Depot Sells a Unit That Never Fit
articles.snippet: The home improvement chain sold its supply unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion.
articles.abstract: The home improvement chain sold its supply unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home Depot agreed yesterday to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion. Members of the consortium — Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice — will take an equal stake in the company.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
articles.snippet: All eyes are on the next steps that Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder, will take to rejuvenate the troubled business.
articles.abstract: All eyes are on the next steps that Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder, will take to rejuvenate the troubled business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should Yahoo stop trying to beat Google at its own game? Should it step up the pace and grow even larger through mergers and acquisitions?
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Insider Trading Can Now Touch Many Corners of the World
articles.snippet: The two men from Pakistan charged with insider trading in connection with the TXU buyout offer have backgrounds that revolve around themes of hubris and aspiration.
articles.abstract: The two men from Pakistan charged with insider trading in connection with the TXU buyout offer have backgrounds that revolve around themes of hubris and aspiration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life in the great Pakistan bull market had been good to Ajaz Rahim. He had a big house in an affluent Karachi neighborhood, a swimming pool with a wave machine and a Yamaha motorcycle that people who know him say he liked to ride without a helmet.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Bloomberg Severs G.O.P. Ties, Fueling Further Talk of ’08 Bid
articles.snippet: The step could clear the way for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to make an independent bid for the presidency.
articles.abstract: The step could clear the way for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to make an independent bid for the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Tuesday that he was dropping his Republican affiliation, a step that could clear the way for him to make an independent bid for the presidency.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Microsoft to Alter Windows Vista
articles.snippet: The changes are in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of the operating system is anticompetitive.
articles.abstract: The changes are in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of the operating system is anticompetitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 20 — Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Truck Bomb Hits Baghdad Mosque, and 61 Are Killed
articles.snippet: The timing, during a major U.S. offensive, seemed intended to demonstrate that insurgents could still strike with near impunity.
articles.abstract: The timing, during a major U.S. offensive, seemed intended to demonstrate that insurgents could still strike with near impunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 19 — A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.

articles.headline: Politics Forcing Detroit to Back New Fuel Rules
articles.snippet: Automakers are lobbying for a modest increase in mileage standards, hoping to silence calls for tougher targets.
articles.abstract: Automakers are lobbying for a modest increase in mileage standards, hoping to silence calls for tougher targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 19 — For a quarter-century, American automakers and their allies argued that any legislation to increase fuel economy standards would rob them of profits, force them to lay off workers and deprive consumers of the vehicles they wanted to buy.

articles.headline: A Lesson That Thomas Could Teach
articles.snippet: The toy train recall shows the realities of offshoring, but it isn’t clear that anyone involved has learned anything.
articles.abstract: The toy train recall shows the realities of offshoring, but it isn’t clear that anyone involved has learned anything.
articles.lead_paragraph: A typical Thomas the Tank Engine story is a little morality play about hubris. The stories take place on the fictional Island of Sodor, where train cars with faces and personalities go about their work.

articles.headline: In the Amazon, Giving Blood but Getting Nothing
articles.snippet: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused widespread suspicions in Brazil.
articles.abstract: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused widespread suspicions in Brazil.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYOWÃ, Brazil — As the Karitiana Indians remember it, the first researchers to draw their blood came here in the late 1970s, shortly after the Amazon tribe began sustained contact with the outside world. In 1996, another team visited, promising medicine if the Karitiana would just give more blood, so they dutifully lined up again.
